Chang and I'm Ari Shapiro many people in the U.S auto industry are breathing a sigh of relief this week the new trade deal between the U.S Mexico and Canada and months of uncertainty if it's approved by Congress it will spare carmakers from some of the terrorists that they had feared
And Wilson is senior vice president of the motor and equipment Manufacturers Association which represents more than a thousand companies that make auto parts you're in the U.S thanks for joining us here on all things considered thank you very glad to be with you to begin with what you just described for listeners what you remember companies making and where you are in the auto making supply chain
So our members make the vast majority of the content for new vehicles and we also manufacture parts and components for maintenance and repair
And how much was on the line for you in this trade agreement where you're holding your breath to see what the details would be

So we are very pleased relieved that all three parties are able to come to an agreement this weekend we're cautiously optimistic that the terms of the green that will work for the industry and for the American public
When you look at the details of the agreement can you tell how it compares to NAFTA for you
Well there's going to be an increase in the amount of North American content that will be required for parts to travel through the three countries can ... the U.S Mexico
States but it counts and all three countries being part of the agreement so we are very pleased relieved to that all three parties were able to come to an agreement this weekend we're cautiously optimistic that the terms of the agreement will work for the industry and for the American public

And in addition there's going to be some new administrative costs that are going to be required one of the concerns we have though are there some new tariffs out there right now on steel and aluminum and we'd like to see Canada and the United states address that before the finalized disagreement in the end of November
So on the one hand there won't be terrible for material crossing Canada U.S Mexico border is on the other hand the steel and aluminum tariffs that were of concern to your industry have not gone away
No they haven't I think one of the things we have the mind as they have been a particular burden to smaller manufacturers many of these smaller manufacturers are only in the U.S
And some of our members have seen the cost of their steel purchases rise almost fifty percent
So this is a significant increase it's typically of concern between Canada and the United states we'd like to see those two countries roll up their sleeves uses same energy they use to conclude this this new NAFTA and be able to come to some kind of agreement on steel and aluminum tariffs

Coakley shut down and became a Superfund site in the mid eighties it was covered with a cap to keep Iran from washing out more toxins
For years this put the public fears to rest then amid news of the cancer cluster and twenty sixteen workers made an alarming discovery high levels of pee fast chemicals in surface waters around the landfill
Since then traces of these industrial toxins have also turned up in nearby wells officials are still working to pinpoint where the chemicals come from
